Award.AwardTitle: Michigan Photonics and Lasers Technician Education and Training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on creating and implementing a Photonics and Lasers Technology Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree program at Baker College of Flint. The new program, unique in Michigan, responds to a documented need for photonics technicians in the state, the Midwest region, and across the United States. The project consists of multiple activities including: developing new curricula, creating a well-equipped optics and photonics laboratory, training faculty to teach in the program, performing outreach activities to area high schools, and educating a first group of students to become photonics technicians. The project also offers opportunities for flexible training of employed technicians and displaced workers. The project leverages broad collaborative work between Baker College of Flint, the newly formed Mi-Light Michigan Photonics Cluster industry group, OP-TEC National Center for Optics and Photonics Education, and Indian Hills Community College. It creates an Associate level Photonics program that encompasses fundamental knowledge and skills in the discipline as well as recent photonics applications that are becoming widely used in diverse industries. The new AAS degree program creates a model that can be adopted by colleges interested in photonics nationwide. Results of the project will be disseminated to educational, industry and professional organizations to reach a wide audience. The project includes efforts to recruit underrepresented minorities and veterans to advanced technological education and training programs. The project supports the advancement of an economically depressed local area and the diversification of the Michigan economy as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project created a new Associate of Applied Science (AAS) program in Photonics and Laser Technology at Baker College of Flint. This program is the only one of its kind in the State of Michigan. It has been developed with industry input to respond to the unmet need for well-prepared photonics technicians in the state and throughout the country. The program prepares technicians to build, test, calibrate, and maintain laser and electro-optic devices and systems. The comprehensive curriculum includes courses in mathematics, physics, computer aided design, electronics, optics, lasers, and photonics applications. A capstone design course and an internship experience with a photonics company are required before graduation.

The project also helped create the infrastructure to deliver experimental laboratories associated with the curriculum. Eight courses in the curriculum have a laboratory component, and lab equipment is also necessary in the capstone design course. The Optics and Photonics Laboratory has been equipped with optical tables, optical components, a wide variety of lasers, and measurement and test equipment. Many of these are industry grade allowing students to acquire the hands-on skills sought by the industry. The laboratory is fully functional and welcomes visitors. In addition to its use for teaching program courses, it has received numerous visits from K-12 students, teachers, counselors, parents and others.

Outreach events to promote the photonics career field and the photonics technician program took place, including presentations in multiple locations, summer camps, and special events celebrating the International Year of Light 2015. More than 1,000 people of all ages and backgrounds were introduced to optics and photonics through presentations, demonstrations, and hands-on activities. Many of them were students in grades 8-12. 

The program has by now produced a first group of graduates who are all working in the photonics industry in the state. They obtained employment with partner companies who actively guide the program as Advisory Board members. In addition to educating the college population enrolled in the program, the “Introduction to Photonics” course has been taught as a dual enrollment course for high school students. This contributes to creating a pipeline of students for the program.

Another impact of the program has been in fostering relationships with organizations such as the Mi-Light Michigan Photonics Cluster, and the Michigan Department of Education Office of Career and Technical Education.

Results of the project have been disseminated through conference presentations, papers published in proceedings, and numerous other means. The project has successfully resulted in the introduction of a new associate level photonics program at Baker College, and in the preparation of a first group of technicians now working in photonics companies in Michigan. The project has laid a solid foundation for the further development of the photonics program, to increase the number of students and graduates, and to provide them with additional knowledge and skills that can help the growing photonics industry in the state and region.  The photonics program has advanced higher education at the College, in the local area, and in the state of Michigan. It benefits the state’s economy, and fosters relationships between diverse organizations. 

Dr. Anca L. Sala, PI

2 August 2016
